author: Yaa Gyasi
description: A novel of breathtaking sweep and emotional power that traces three hundred years in Ghana and along the way also becomes a truly great American novel. Extraordinary for its exquisite language, its implacable sorrow, its soaring beauty, and for its monumental portrait of the forces that shape families and nations,
title: Homegoing

author: Colson Whitehead
description: Cora is a slave on a cotton plantation in Georgia. Life is hellish for all the slaves but especially bad for Cora; an outcast even among her fellow Africans, she is coming into womanhood - where even greater pain awaits. When Caesar, a recent arrival from Virginia, tells her about the Underground Railroad, they decide to take a terrifying risk and escape. Matters do not go
title: The Underground Railroad

author: Paul Kalanithi
description: For readers of Atul Gawande, Andrew Solomon, and Anne Lamott, a profoundly moving, exquisitely observed memoir by a young neurosurgeon faced with a terminal cancer diagnosis who attempts to answer the question What makes a life worth living?
title: When Breath Becomes Air

author: Matthew Desmond
description:
New York Times Bestseller

From Harvard sociologist and MacArthur "Genius" Matthew Desmond, a landmark work of scholarship and reportage that will forever change the way we look at poverty in America
title: Evicted: Poverty and Profit in the American City

author: Ian McGuire
description: LONGLISTED FOR THE MAN BOOKER PRIZE 2016
publisher: Henry Holt and Co.                          (first published February 11th 2016
title: The North Water

author: Han Kang
description: Before the nightmare, Yeong-hye and her husband lived an ordinary life. But when splintering, blood-soaked images start haunting her thoughts, Yeong-hye decides to purge her mind and renounce eating meat. In a country where societal mores are strictly obeyed, Yeong-hye's decision to embrace a more “plant-like” existence is a shocking act of subversion. And as her passive r
title: The Vegetarian

author: Karan Mahajan
description: FINALIST FOR THE NATIONAL BOOK AWARD 2016
title: The Association of Small Bombs

author: Ann Patchett
description: #1 New York Times Bestseller
title: Commonwealth

author: Elizabeth Strout
description: The profound mother-daughter bond is explored through a mother's hospital visit to her estranged daughter by the Pulitzer Prize-winning author of Olive Kitteridge and The Burgess Boys.
title: My Name Is Lucy Barton

author: Zadie Smith
description: Two brown girls dream of being dancers--but only one, Tracey, has talent. The other has ideas: about rhythm and time, about black bodies and black music, about what constitutes a tribe, or makes a person truly free. It's a close but complicated childhood friendship that ends abruptly in their early twenties, never to be revisited, but never quite forgotten, either.
title: Swing Time

author: Madeleine Thien
description: “In a single year, my father left us twice. The first time, to end his marriage, and the second, when he took his own life. I was ten years old.”
publisher: W. W. Norton  Company                          (first published May 31st 2016
title: Do Not Say We Have Nothing

author: Nathan  Hill
description: A hilarious and deeply touching debut novel about a son, the mother who left him as a child, and how his search to uncover the secrets of her life leads him to reclaim his own.
title: The Nix

author: Deborah Levy
description: Sofia, a young anthropologist, has spent much of her life trying to solve the mystery of her mother's unexplainable illness. She's frustrated with Rose and her constant complaints but utterly relieved to be called to abandon her own disappointing fledgling adult life. She and Rose travel to the searing, arid coast of southern Spain to see a famous consultant, Dr. Gomez—the
title: Hot Milk

author: Jane Mayer
description: Why is America living in an age of profound economic inequality? Why, despite the desperate need to address climate change, have even modest environmental efforts been defeated again and again? Why have protections for employees been decimated? Why do hedge-fund billionaires pay a far lower tax rate than middle-class workers?
title: Dark Money: The Hidden History of the Billionaires Behind the Rise of the Radical Right

author: Affinity Konar
description: Pearl is in charge of: the sad, the good, the past.
title: Mischling

author: Noah Hawley
description: On a foggy summer night, eleven people—ten privileged, one down-on-his-luck painter—depart Martha's Vineyard on a private jet headed for New York. Sixteen minutes later, the unthinkable happens: the plane plunges into the ocean. The only survivors are the painter Scott Burroughs and a four-year-old boy, who is now the last remaining member of an immensely wealthy and power
title: Before the Fall

author: Svetlana Alexievich
description: From the 2015 winner of the Nobel Prize in Literature, Svetlana Alexievich, comes the first English translation of her latest work, an oral history of the disintegration of the Soviet Union and the emergence of a new Russia.
title: Secondhand Time: The Last of the Soviets

author: Ian McEwan
description: Nutshell is a classic story of murder and deceit, told by a narrator with a perspective and voice unlike any in recent literature. A bravura performance, it is the finest recent work from a true master.
title: Nutshell

author: Hisham Matar
description: From Man Booker Prize and National Book Critics Circle Award finalist Hisham Matar, a memoir of his journey home to his native Libya in search of answers to his father's disappearance. In 2012, after the overthrow of Qaddafi, the acclaimed novelist Hisham Matar journeys to his native Libya after an absence of thirty years.
title: The Return: Fathers, Sons, and the Land in Between

author: Carol  Anderson
description: From the Civil War to our combustible present, acclaimed historian Carol Anderson reframes our continuing conversation about race, chronicling the powerful forces opposed to black progress in America.
title: White Rage: The Unspoken Truth of Our Racial Divide

author: Louise Erdrich
description: In this literary masterwork, Louise Erdrich, the bestselling author of the National Book Award-winning
title: LaRose

author: Michael Chabon
description: Following on the heels of his
title: Moonglow

author: Don DeLillo
description: The wisest, richest, funniest, and most moving novel in years from Don DeLillo, one of the great American novelists of our time—an ode to language, at the heart of our humanity, a meditation on death, and an embrace of life.
title: Zero K

author: Jonathan Safran Foer
description: A monumental new novel from the bestselling author of
title: Here I Am

author: David Szalay
description: A magnificent and ambitiously conceived portrait of contemporary life, by a genius of realism.
title: All That Man Is

author: Max Porter
description: In a London flat, two young boys face the unbearable sadness of their mother's sudden death. Their father, a Ted Hughes scholar and scruffy romantic, imagines a future of well-meaning visitors and emptiness.
title: Grief is the Thing with Feathers

author: Jacqueline Woodson
description: Running into a long-ago friend sets memories from the 1970s in motion for August, transporting her to a time and a place where friendship was everything—until it wasn’t. For August and her girls, sharing confidences as they ambled through neighborhood streets, Brooklyn was a place where they believed that they were beautiful, talented, brilliant—a part of a future that bel
title: Another Brooklyn

author: Hope Jahren
description: Acclaimed scientist Hope Jahren has built three laboratories in which she’s studied trees, flowers, seeds, and soil. Her first book is a revelatory treatise on plant life—but it is also so much more.
title: Lab Girl

author: Annie Proulx
description: In the late seventeenth century two penniless young Frenchmen, René Sel and Charles Duquet, arrive in New France. Bound to a feudal lord, a “
title: Barkskins

author: Cathy O'Neil
description: A former Wall Street quant sounds an alarm on mathematical modeling—a pervasive new force in society that threatens to undermine democracy and widen inequality.
title: Weapons of Math Destruction: How Big Data Increases Inequality and Threatens Democracy

author: C.E. Morgan
description: Hellsmouth, a wilful thoroughbred filly, has the legacy of a family riding on her.
title: The Sport of Kings

author: Imbolo Mbue
description:
A compulsively readable debut novel about marriage, immigration, class, race, and the trapdoors in the American Dream—the unforgettable story of a young Cameroonian couple making a new life in New York just as the Great Recession upends the economy

Named one of BuzzFeed’s “Incredible New Books You Need to Read This Summer”
title: Behold the Dreamers

author: Eileen Myles
description: A collection of thrilling new and beloved past work from one of America's most celebrated poets, Eileen Myles, a cult icon and modern favorite
title: I Must Be Living Twice: New and Selected Poems

author: Richard Russo
description: Richard Russo, at the very top of his game, now returns to North Bath, in upstate New York, and the characters who made Nobody's Fool (1993) a "confident, assured novel that sweeps the reader up," according to the San Francisco Chronicle back then. "Simple as family love, yet nearly as complicated." Or, as The Boston Globe put it, "a big, rambunctious novel with endless ri
title: Everybody's Fool

author: Bruce Springsteen
description: “Writing about yourself is a funny business…But in a project like this, the writer has made one promise, to show the reader his mind. In these pages, I’ve tried to do this.” —Bruce Springsteen, from the pages of
title: Born to Run

author: Juan Gabriel Vásquez
description: From the brilliant mind of the author of
title: Reputations

author: Tyler Anbinder
description: A defining American story of millions of immigrants, hundreds of languages, and one great city
title: City of Dreams: The 400-Year Epic History of Immigrant New York

author: Siddhartha Mukherjee
description: From the Pulitzer Prize-winning, bestselling author of
title: The Gene: An Intimate History

author: Simon Schama
description: A portrait opens a window into a person's life: who they were and wanted to be, who the artist saw and how everyone else looked on.
title: The Face of Britain: The Nation Through its Portraits

author: Candice Millard
description: From New York Times bestselling author of Destiny of the Republic and The River of Doubt, a thrilling narrative of Winston Churchill's extraordinary and little-known exploits during the Boer War
publisher: Random House Large Print                          (first published April 12th 2016
title: Hero of the Empire: The Boer War, a Daring Escape, and the Making of Winston Churchill

author: David France
description: The definitive history of the successful battle to halt the AIDS epidemic from the creator of, and inspired by, the seminal documentary How to Survive a Plague.
title: How to Survive a Plague: The Inside Story of How Citizens and Science Tamed AIDS

author: Elizabeth Hinton
description: In the United States today, one in every 31 adults is under some form of penal control, including one in eleven African American men. How did the "land of the free" become the home of the world's largest prison system? Challenging the belief that America's prison problem originated with the Reagan administration's War on Drugs, Elizabeth Hinton traces the rise of mass inca
title: From the War on Poverty to the War on Crime: The Making of Mass Incarceration in America

author: Blanche Wiesen Cook
description: The magisterial concluding volume in the definitive biography of Eleanor Roosevelt
title: Eleanor Roosevelt, Volume 3: The War Years and After, 1939-1962

author: Francine Prose
description: The acclaimed
title: Mister Monkey

author: Ruth Franklin
description: Instantly heralded for its “masterful” and “thrilling” portrayal (
title: Shirley Jackson: A Rather Haunted Life

author: Nancy Isenberg
description: In her groundbreaking history of the class system in America, extending from colonial times to the present, Nancy Isenberg takes on our comforting myths about equality, uncovering the crucial legacy of the ever-present, always embarrassing––if occasionally entertaining––"poor white trash."
title: White Trash: The 400-Year Untold History of Class in America

author: Derek Palacio
description: Derek Palacio’s stunning, mythic novel marks the arrival of a fresh voice and a new chapter in the history of 21st century Cuban-American literature.
title: The Mortifications

author: Wendy  Warren
description: The most important work on seventeenth-century New England in a generation.
title: New England Bound: Slavery and Colonization in Early America

author: Rebecca Traister
description: A nuanced investigation into the sexual, economic, and emotional lives of women in America. In a provocative, groundbreaking work, National Magazine Award finalist Rebecca Traister, “the most brilliant voice on feminism in the country” (Anne Lamott), traces the history of unmarried and late-married women in America who, through social, political, and economic means, have r
title: All the Single Ladies: Unmarried Women and the Rise of an Independent Nation

author: Jeffrey Toobin
description: From New Yorker staff writer and bestselling author Jeffrey Toobin, the definitive account of the kidnapping and trial that defined an insane era in American history
title: American Heiress: The Wild Saga of the Kidnapping, Crimes and Trial of Patty Hearst

author: Nicole Y. Dennis-Benn
description: Capturing the distinct rhythms of Jamaican life and dialect, Nicole Dennis-Benn pens a tender hymn to a world hidden among pristine beaches and the wide expanse of turquoise seas. At an opulent resort in Montego Bay, Margot hustles to send her younger sister, Thandi, to school. Taught as a girl to trade her sexuality for survival, Margot is ruthlessly determined to shield
title: Here Comes the Sun

author: Patrick Phillips
description: A gripping tale of racial cleansing in Forsyth County, Georgia, and a harrowing testament to the deep roots of racial violence in America.
title: Blood at the Root: A Racial Cleansing in America

author: Ethan Michaeli
description:
“An extraordinary history…Deeply researched, elegantly written…a towering achievement that will not be soon forgotten.” —Brent Staples, New York Times Book Review

NAMED ONE OF THE BEST BOOKS OF THE YEAR BY 
The New York Times Book Review • The Washington Post • Amazon
 
Giving voice to the voiceless, the Chicago Defender condemned Jim Crow, catalyzed the Great Migration, and
title: The Defender: How the Legendary Black Newspaper Changed America

author: Jessi Klein
description: INSTANT
title: You'll Grow Out of It

author: Andrew Solomon
description: From the winner of the National Book Award and the National Books Critics’ Circle Award—and one of the most original thinkers of our time—a riveting collection of essays about places in dramatic transition.
title: Far & Away: Reporting from the Brink of Change: Seven Continents, Twenty-Five Years

author: Ed Yong
description: Joining the ranks of popular science classics like The Botany of Desire and The Selfish Gene, a groundbreaking, wondrously informative, and vastly entertaining examination of the most significant revolution in biology since Darwin—a “microbe’s-eye view” of the world that reveals a marvelous, radically reconceived picture of life on earth.
title: I Contain Multitudes: The Microbes Within Us and a Grander View of Life

author: Adrienne Rich
description: Adrienne Rich was the singular voice of her generation and one of our most important American poets. She brought discussions of gender, race, and class to the forefront of poetical discourse, pushing formal boundaries and consistently examining both self and society.
publisher: W. W. Norton  Company                          (first published March 28th 2016
title: Collected Poems: 1950–2012

author: Mitchell Duneier
description: A five-hundred-year story of exclusion and containment, from the first Jewish ghetto to the present
publisher: Farrar, Straus and Giroux                          (first published December 1st 2015
title: Ghetto: The Invention of a Place, the History of an Idea

author: Joseph Lelyveld
description: A New York Times 2016 Notable Book
title: His Final Battle: The Last Months of Franklin Roosevelt

author: Boris Fishman
description: The author of the critically admired, award-winning
title: Don't Let My Baby Do Rodeo

author: Magda Szabó
description: When Ettie's husband dies, her daughter Iza insists that her mother give up the family house in the countryside and move to Budapest. Displaced from her community and her home, Ettie tries to find her place in this new life, but can't seem to get it right. She irritates the maid, hangs food outside the window because she mistrusts the fridge and, in her naivety and lonelin
title: Iza's Ballad

author: Robert Tombs
description: In
title: The English and their History

author: Solmaz Sharif
description:
*Finalist for the 2017 PEN Open Book Award*
*Finalist for the 2016 National Book Award*
title: Look

author: Alexander Weinstein
description: AN EXTRAORDINARILY RESONANT AND PROPHETIC COLLECTION OF SPECULATIVE SHORT FICTION FOR OUR TECH-
title: Children of the New World

author: Edna O'Brien
description: The much-anticipated new novel from the literary world's master of storytelling, Edna O'Brien.
publisher: Little Brown and Company                          (first published October 27th 2015
title: The Little Red Chairs

author: Michael V. Hayden
description: An unprecedented high-level master narrative of America's intelligence wars, from the only person ever to helm both CIA and NSA, at a time of heinous new threats and wrenching change
title: Playing to the Edge: American Intelligence in the Age of Terror

author: Joy Williams
description: Pulitzer Prize and National Book Award finalist Joy Williams has a one-of-a-kind gift for capturing both the absurdity and the darkness of everyday life. In Ninety-Nine Stories of God, she takes on one of mankind's most confounding preoccupations: the Supreme Being.This series of short, fictional vignettes explores our day-to-day interactions with an ever-elusive and arbit
title: Ninety-Nine Stories of God

author: Sarah Bakewell
description: Paris, near the turn of 1933. Three young friends meet over apricot cocktails at the Bec-de-Gaz bar on the rue Montparnasse. They are Jean-Paul Sartre, Simone de Beauvoir and their friend Raymond Aron, who opens their eyes to a radical new way of thinking. Pointing to his drink, he says, 'You can make philosophy out of
title: At the Existentialist Café: Freedom, Being, and Apricot Cocktails

author: Arlie Russell Hochschild
description: In
title: Strangers in Their Own Land: Anger and Mourning on the American Right

author: Susan Faludi
description: From the Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist and bestselling author of Backlash, comes In the Darkroom, an astonishing confrontation with the enigma of her father and the larger riddle of identity consuming our age.
title: In the Darkroom

author: Peter Ho Davies
description: From the author of The Welsh Girl comes a groundbreaking, provocative new novel.
title: The Fortunes

author: Jonathan Lethem
description: Handsome, impeccably tuxedoed Bruno Alexander travels the world winning large sums of money from amateur "whales" who think they can challenge his peerless acumen at backgammon. Fronted by his pasty, vampiric manager, Edgar Falk, Bruno arrives in Berlin after a troubling run of bad luck in Singapore. Perhaps it was the chance encounter with his crass childhood acquaintance
title: A Gambler's Anatomy

author: Robert F. Worth
description: The definitive work of literary journalism on the Arab Spring and its troubled aftermath
publisher: Farrar, Straus and Giroux                          (first published March 22nd 2016
title: A Rage for Order: The Middle East in Turmoil, from Tahrir Square to ISIS

author: Lara Vapnyar
description: A profound and dazzlingly entertaining novel from the writer Louis Menand calls "Jane Austen with a Russian soul"
title: Still Here

author: Stefan Hertmans
description: Shortly before his death in 1981, Stefan Hertmans' grandfather gave him a couple of filled exercise books. Stories he’d heard as a child had led Hertmans to suspect that their contents might be disturbing, and for years he didn’t dare to open them.
title: War and Turpentine

author: Matti Friedman
description: “Matti Friedman’s haunting war memoir reminds one of Michael Herr’s unforgettable Vietnam memoir, Dispatches. It, too, is destined to become a classic text on the absurdities of war. Evocative, emotionally wrenching, and yet clear-eyed and dispassionate, Pumpkinflowers is a stunning achievement.” —Kai Bird, Pulitzer Prize–winning biographer and New York Times bestselling a
title: Pumpkinflowers: A Soldier's Story of a Forgotten War

author: Maria Semple
description: A genius novel from the author of Where'd You Go, Bernadette, about a day in the life of Eleanor Flood, forced to abandon her small ambitions when she awakes to a strange, new future unfolding.
title: Today Will Be Different

author: Beth Macy
description: The true story of two African-American brothers who were kidnapped and displayed as circus freaks, and whose mother endured a 28-year struggle to get them back.
title: Truevine: Two Brothers, a Kidnapping, and a Mother's Quest: A True Story of the Jim Crow South

author: Stephen King
description: The spectacular finale to the New York Times bestselling trilogy that began with Mr. Mercedes (winner of the Edgar Award) and Finders Keepers—In End of Watch, the diabolical “Mercedes Killer” drives his enemies to suicide, and if Bill Hodges and Holly Gibney don’t figure out a way to stop him, they’ll be victims themselves.
title: End of Watch

author: Adam Kirsch
description: Jews have long embraced their identity as “the people of the book.” But outside of the Bible, much of the Jewish literary tradition remains little known to nonspecialist readers.
title: The People and the Books: 18 Classics of Jewish Literature

author: Adam Kirsch
description: Jews have long embraced their identity as “the people of the book.” But outside of the Bible, much of the Jewish literary tradition remains little known to nonspecialist readers.
title: The People and the Books: 18 Classics of Jewish Literature

author: Louise Doughty
description: From the author of
title: Black Water

author: Rosa Brooks
description: The first serious book to examine what happens when the ancient boundary between war and peace is erased.
title: How Everything Became War and the Military Became Everything: Tales from the Pentagon

author: Peter Fritzsche
description: World War II reached into the homes and lives of ordinary people in an unprecedented way. Civilians made up the vast majority of those killed by war. On Europe’s home front, the war brought the German blitzkrieg, followed by long occupations and the racial genocide of the Holocaust.
title: An Iron Wind: Europe Under Hitler

author: Melanie Finn
description: Pilgrim's husband left her for another woman, stranding her in a Swiss town where she is involved in an accident that leaves three children dead. Cleared of responsibility though overcome with guilt, she absconds to Africa, befriending a series of locals each with their own tragic past.
title: The Gloaming

author: Heather Ann Thompson
description: The first definitive account of the infamous 1971 Attica prison uprising, the state’s violent response, and the victims' decades-long quest for justice including information never released to the public published to coincide with the forty-fifth anniversary of this historic event.
title: Blood in the Water: The Attica Prison Uprising of 1971 and Its Legacy

author: Ishion Hutchinson
description: A stunning collection that traverses the borders of culture and time, from the 2011 winner of the PEN/Joyce Osterweil Award
title: House of Lords and Commons: Poems

author: David Constantine
description: The long anticipated novel from the author of the short story 'In Another Country', which inspired the Oscar/Academy Award nominated film, #45Years.
title: The Life-Writer

author: Martin Seay
description: The core story is set in Venice in the sixteenth century, when the famed makers of Venetian glass were perfecting one of the old world's most wondrous inventions: the mirror. An object of glittering yet fearful fascination—was it reflecting simple reality, or something more spiritually revealing?—the Venetian mirrors were state of the art technology and subject to industri
title: The Mirror Thief

author: Dan Fox
description: Pretentiousness
title: Pretentiousness: Why It Matters

author: Daniel Bergner
description: The touching, triumphant story of a young black man's journey from violence and despair to one of the world's most elite artistic institutions, as if The Blind Side were set in the world of opera.
title: Sing for Your Life: A Story of Race, Music, and Family

author: Lauren Collins
description: A language barrier is no match for love. Lauren Collins discovered this firsthand when, in her early thirties, she moved to London and fell for a Frenchman named Olivier—a surprising turn of events for someone who didn’t have a passport until she was in college. But what does it mean to love someone in a second language? Collins wonders, as her relationship with Olivier co
title: When in French: Love in a Second Language

author: Steve Fraser
description: No political metaphor in recent American history has enjoyed the impact of the limousine liberal. Taking aim at what many consider the hypocrisy of wealthy liberals who champion the cause of the poor but who have no intention of bearing the costs of doing anything about their plight, it has mobilized an enduring politics of resentment against everything from civil rights t
title: The Limousine Liberal: How an Incendiary Image United the Right and Fractured America

author: Sebastian Mallaby
description: The definitive biography of the most important economic statesman of our time
title: The Man Who Knew: The Life and Times of Alan Greenspan

author: Jenny Diski
description: The future flashed before my eyes in all its pre-ordained banality. Embarrassment, at first, to the exclusion of all other feelings. But embarrassment curled at the edges with a weariness …
title: In Gratitude

author: Sabina Murray
description: Following her New York Times Editor’s Choice collection of short stories Tales of the New World, historical fiction master Sabina Murray returns with an epic and bold novel of friendship and betrayal set across four continents and a 40-year time span
title: Valiant Gentlemen

author: Lucy Wood
description: An alternative cover edition for this ISBN can be found here
title: Weathering

author: Robert J. Gordon
description: In the century after the Civil War, an economic revolution improved the American standard of living in ways previously unimaginable. Electric lighting, indoor plumbing, motor vehicles, air travel, and television transformed households and workplaces. But has that era of unprecedented growth come to an end? Weaving together a vivid narrative, historical anecdotes, and econo
title: The Rise and Fall of American Growth: The U.S. Standard of Living Since the Civil War

author: Simon Callow
description: The third volume of Simon Callow’s acclaimed Orson Welles biography, covering the period of his exile from America (1947–1964), when he produced some of his greatest works, including Touch of Evil
title: Orson Welles, Vol. 3: One-Man Band

description: The third volume of Simon Callow’s acclaimed Orson Welles biography, covering the period of his exile from America (1947–1964), when he produced some of his greatest works, including Touch of Evil
